passages.text: Central Asia Emerging Europe Middle East Sub- Saharan Africa

Week in CEEMEA. In Egypt, the CBE cut its policy rate by 200bp amid favorable inflation developments, coming in line with our out- of- consensus call. In Hungary and Kazakhstan, the NBH and NBK have both left their policy rates unchanged at \(6.50\%\) and \(16.5\%\) , respectively. Central bank meetings aside, in Poland, CPI print was out this morning and showed the headline inflation easing to \(2.8\%\) in August.

What you need to know for the week ahead. In terms of data, August CPI is due across a number of countries in the region next week. We see an easing in headline inflation in Turkiye, Uzbekistan, and in the Czech Republic. Modest upward pressures are, however, expected in Ghana and Kazakhstan. Q2 GDP data for Turkiye will also be out next week, and we expect growth to decelerate in Q2 amidst domestic and global headwind. Finally, August PMIs are due across the CEEMEA region next week.

Poland: discussing NBP, inflation and fiscal. The NBP is due to meet for its September MPC meeting next week, and in our baseline scenario we expect the MPC to deliver a 25bps rate cut to take the policy rate to \(4.75\%\) . Recent NBP communication, and inflation dynamics data support our view. However, the increase in fiscal risks (as reiterated by the 2026 draft budget confirmed this week) and the ongoing uncertainty on the future of electricity prices, a pause in easing should not be completely ruled out for next week in our view.

EM FX: Crowning glory The Czech crown has been one of our highest bullish conviction views this year. Having performed well against both the euro and PLN, which has been has been our preferred expression since the May Blueprint were remain structurally bullish. Indeed, we see the Czech exchange rates as one of the best expressions of the regime shift in German fiscal and defence policy. 1. Czechia's growth is highly correlated to Germany, and should benefit from spillovers from German fiscal stimulus. 2. The economy already enjoys a strong comparative advantage in defence, and exports of defence equipment are already rapidly increasing. 3. The labour market is close to full employment, meaning stronger growth could translate into wage pressures. 4. Low realised vol offers a great investment opportunity, especially via FX options.
EM Sovereign Credit Datapack (August 2025). Our EM Sovereign Credit

Datapack is a collection of data and analysis on debt, fiscal, macroeconomic and financial market metrics. We attempt to standardize data concepts and update with the latest figures. All the data are presented in a dashboard- style display to allow for easy comparison across EM countries.

CountryAsset classFundamentals/DriversCEEMEA low-yieldersTop TradesCzech RepublicEconomicsEconomic sentiment has improved since the announcement of the German fiscal package earlier this year. A stronger domestic demand recovery, along with improved sentiment means that the growth outcome is likely to be stronger than earlier expected, despite the larger US tariffs. That said, still cautious household spending and a difficult external environment, means that we only expect a modest growth recovery this year. We believe that inflation will likely moderate in the next few months due to weak growth, still-tight fiscal policy, absence of wage spiral risks, and weak imported inflation (though upside risk exists from services inflation and high rentals). In our baseline scenario, we do not expect the CNB to ease policy rates further in this cycle. Main risks stem from further escalation in global trade war, as well as escalation in geopolitical tensions. Election due in autumn 2025 also pose a risk. FX weakness and fiscal slippages remain risks to the outlook.Cash bonds: overweightInflation has been coming off from recent peaks, but underlying price pressures remain sticky. Nevertheless, we still like local bonds and continue to expect an outperformance vs core rates in H2. Inflation dynamics should improve further with room to reach 2% by year-end - further supported by our bullish view on FX. ASW-spreads have tightened, however, term-premium in bonds remains high. This is combination with cheap valuation, light foreign positioning and low net supply in H2, provide value for local bonds in our view. On the back of the underperformance vs CEE peers earlier this summer, we have moved from a modest overweight to overweight. We like the SY-7Y part of the curve and think it offers better risk-reward from an outright perspective compared to Polish bonds. Additionally, we continue to like Czech ultra green a very steep curve, and our view of no overshooting on fiscal.Local rates: lowerRecent upside inflation surprises and a hawkish CNB have driven an aggressive bear-flattening of the CZK curve, almost fully pricing out all rate cuts. In turn, we now see an opportunity to re-enter outright receivers. Despite near-term inflation headwinds, we expect inflation to fall back below 2% making cuts still more likely than hikes this year (or next year). We acknowledge the challenges for our call, but we still find risk reward as attractive in short-term recessions.1y1y CZK receivers &amp; long 10Y ASW-spread tighterFX: bullishWe are constructive on CZK given the CNB have signalled another pause, and PMIs are now showing some recovery, even if valuations remain elevated. Czechia should also benefit from German fiscal stimulus and defense spendingshort PLN/CZKHungaryEconomicsGrowth is likely to remain weak this year, due to weak external demand and subdued economic sentiment. Hungary is one of the countries most vulnerable to a global trade shock (due to high exposure to global trade, China, and European manufacturing). Inflation has remained elevated at the beginning of the year, mainly due to food and services repricing. However, declining energy prices and government's interventions are likely to lead to more moderate inflation ahead. NBH remains hawkish - and near-term rate easing is unlikely. Renewed disinflation, amidst growth concerns, should allow the central bank to resume rate cuts in 2025, but these are likely to be back-loaded to Q4-25 and early 2026. More persistent inflationary pressures, fiscal shortfalls, and further delays to EU fund flows remain key risks, along with US trade policy shifts and potential escalation in geopolitical conflicts.Cash bonds: strong overweightBonds have seen modest selling pressure this week with concerns about developments in France spilling over into CEE. However, domestically, the fundamentals still look supportive. Disinflation remains on track, although July's inflation slightly exceeded consensus expectations (but aligned with DB Economics' forecast). This trend is underpinned by a strengthening currency, persistent subdued domestic activity data, slowing wage growth and the recent significant drop in oil prices. We anticipate headline CPI falling to 3.5% by year-end, creating scope for gradual monetary easing in late 2025/early 2026. We maintain our bullish strategy view driven by not only supportive fundamentals, but also technicals, attractive steady-state return characteristics, and compelling valuations. Specifically, the market currently prices in a too high terminal rate, foreign positioning remains very light, supply dynamics are well balanced and local bonds offer high term premium, and wide ASW spreads. In addition, real interest rates remain elevated. Our fair value models further reinforce this view, indicating that local assets are undervalued, particularly duration bonds. We maintain a strong overweight, expecting continued outperformance of duration bonds relative to CEE peers, especially Romania. Our year-end target for the 10-year bond yield is 6.25%, compared to the current ~7.0%.Local rates: lowerWe recently shifted from roll-rich curve flattens into outright receivers in 6x9 FRAs and 5y5y. We justify this with our view that all three a) the pace of easing, b) the terminal rate and c) term premium are too hawkish/high-priced - particularly vs CEE peers and core rates. On the back of the recent bull-flattening, the short-end of the curve looks closer to fair with just a few bps left in receivers. On the other hand 5y5y still has much more to go in our view. We target 6.0% in 6x9 FRAs (entry: 6.23) and 6.75% in 5y5y (entry: 7.20).Top trades: 5y5y IRS &amp; 6x9 FRA receiversFX: neutralWe worry about structural risks to HUF (the risk of expansionary fiscal policy into next year's election, a very weak growth outlook and a poor relationship with the EU) but there are also some long term upsides, especially if the opposition win in next year's election, releasing EU funds. In the near term, we don't see catalysts for significant weakness in the next two to three months assuming the NBH stick to an extremely cautious approach.-IsraelEconomicsEconomy experienced a contraction at rate 3.5% saar in Q2 as conflict with Iran in June weighed on investment and consumption. On the other hand, leading indicators in July and onwards, indicate a quick recovery in activity post ceasefire with Iran. While fragile investment confidence and headwinds from global trade tariffs remain as obstacles for growth prospects, we expect recent downshift in conflict to encourage gradual recovery in economy whereas protracted conflict in Gaza should prevent a quick recovery to pre-war trend. Inflation remained above target range at 3.1% YoY as of July. While inflation still remains above target range of the BOI and recent escalation in conflict add further uncertainty to short term prints, we remain constructive on disinflation in H2-2025. As a result, we expect the BOI to resume its easing cycle in H2-25. This expectation is based on lower geopolitical risks and anticipated easing inflationary pressures. We forecast the policy rate at 4.25% by the end of 2025, with a single 25bps cut in H2-2025 though the timing of it will hinge on the course of geopolitical developments.Cash bonds: modest overweightAfter the strong June rally, valuation no longer looks attractive and bonds screen rich compared to fundamental drivers. We still expect price pressures to improve significantly over the upcoming months due to supply-side improvements, lower energy prices, and a gradual economic recovery. The pace of the easing cycle is currently priced in line with our expectations, however, the market is still pricing the terminal rate ~75bps above neutral (3%) which offers value for bonds in the belly. Foreign positioning is less crowded now but has not declined below the long-term average. Overall, we have maintained a constructive outlook and expect decent performance in H2. However, we think the upside potential for Israeli bonds is more limited compared to peers, given recent outperformance leading to rich valuation and concerns about more supply in H2. We maintain a modest overweight but shift from duration into 5Y bonds.Local rates: lowerWe recommend investors shift into outright 5Y IRS receivers on the back of the recent bull-flattening. With the expected start of the easing cycle, we expect outright terminal rate receivers to perform better than curve flattens with further risks to the long-end due to higher fiscal spending in H2.Top trade: receive 5Y ILSFX: structurally bullishWe remain structurally constructive on the shekel, which has shrugged off recent geopolitical developments. Previously, Israel's basic balance saw a decline due to record portfolio outflows, despite the current account improving and FDI slowing. But when it comes to foreign flows, we see scope for a recovery given a) positioning is underweight, b) the BoI could move to a looser stance once the current geopolitical tensions ease, encouraging bond inflows c) political developments could turn more favourable again. On the flipside, there is also scope for Israeli institutional investors to add to hedges to US assets.-
Source:Deutsche Bank

CountryAsset classFundamentals/DriversCEEMEA low-yielders (contd.)Top TradesPolandEconomicsGrowth is likely to remain stronger than in the rest of CE3 this year, despite a weak external backdrop and uncertainty weighing on household demand. The country's more diversified economy and strong EU funds absorption next year make Poland slightly less vulnerable to trade shocks. Inflation is likely to remain close to 3% in H2-2025, allowing the central bank to ease policy rates. We can see policy rate at 4.25% by end-2025 and terminal rate of 3.75% to be reached in Q1-26. The fiscal outlook and potential further slippages this year remain a major risk. Policy uncertainty and friction between President and the government is likely to continue.Cash bonds: modest overweightPolish bonds came under pressure this week on the back of news that the fiscal deficit this year would be higher than planned. However, a softer August inflation print provided some support towards the end of the week. Although bonds are cheap in our models, we still find risk-reward more attractive in ASW-spread tighteners (belly or long-end). Inflation is coming down sharply in Q3 and we expect more monetary policy easing, but both are now well priced in. We remain structurally bullish on the back of sharply falling inflation in H2, light positioning, and attractive steady-state return characteristics as well as cheap valuation vs domestic drivers. We continue to express a modest overweight and see value in both, 5Y &amp; 10Y bonds, but expect an underperformance vs Czech bonds, especially in Q4-25.Local rates: neutralAlthough we find the terminal rate as too divisive, we stay neutral given favorable near-term inflation dynamics and potential more rate cuts in September. Risk-reward remains more attractive in ASW-spreads tighteners rather than outright rates.5Y bonds vs 1y1y IRS payers / 10Y ASW-spreads tightenersFX: bearishWe like tactically selling zloty over the summer. Relatively high interest rates have been crucial in keeping CEE FX relatively insulated from the growth shock of the last three years. But monetary policy divergence will stand out over the next four months, with the NBP likely to continue easing from July. The CNB and NBP are far more cautious, even if real rates are arguably too high in both economies. Second, there is divergence on the flow front as well, with Poland's current account tipping back into deficit in the first quarter of this year, while both Hungary and the Czech Republic's remain in surplus. We are especially concerned about the marked slowdown in Polish export growth relative to its CEE peers, even more so as Poland should in theory be less sensitive to auto tariffs. Basic balances have favored Poland for the last two years, but with FDI also slowing, this may be over. Finally, Polish fiscal policy is becoming increasingly concerning, with the budget deficit projected to be close to 6% this year, in excess of Hungary's.short PLN/CZKRomaniaEconomicsProlonged political uncertainty, and ongoing fiscal consolidation are leading to a slowdown in domestic activity. Indirect tax increases, and expiry of energy price protections will likely lead to sharply higher inflation in the near-term, and prevent the NBR from easing policy until at least H1-26. The approved fiscal consolidation package is positive in terms of scope and targets, and though challenges remain, we think risks of a credit rating downgrade this year has declined. Slow fiscal consolidation and a still-structurally-wide current account deficit, along with potential delays to EU fund inflows and potential credit rating downgrades are the main risks.Cash bonds: neutralWith some of the larger downside risks for Romania likely averted, the outlook has become more balanced. However, we think fundamentals still look challenging, with a still wide fiscal deficit despite improvements and electricity price caps expiring and the VAT hike adding to inflationary pressures. Technicals don't look supportive either, especially as supply pressure is likely to remain high following an issuance shortfall in H1 and the authorities continuing to face high financing requirements. Steady-state return characteristics are a mixed bag but ASW-spreads are pretty tight and term premium is very low. Overall, we maintain our neutral stance on Romania and continue to expect underperformance vs Hungary and think a more constructive view on Romania is best expressed in 5Y bonds that we expect to outperform compared to the wings.RussiaFX: neutralRON continues to screen overvalued and structurally a weaker currency would be justified in light of persistent twin deficits. However, more recently momentum has swung into a more supportive direction. The pro-European, centrist parties have been able to form a broad coalition government and a fiscal consolidation package is forthcoming. Additionally, the NBR will likely remain cautious with regard to still sticky headline inflation and high FX pass-through. FX reserves have seen a pronounced decline in May but remain at robust levels and have already started to recover in June. Bringing it all together, we think the direction of travel remains towards further currency weakness but see room for the leu to narrowly outperform forwards into year-end.-EconomicsFundamentals/DriversCEEMEA high-yieldersTop TradesSouth AfricaEconomicsThe US push for peace between Russia and Ukraine quickly ran into difficulties amid still wide differences in minimal war aims and Moscow's unwillingness to compromise. We see potential for more constructive talks later in 2025, but this requires greater US pressure on Moscow and/or Ukraine negating Russia's military initiative. Russia's economy overheated in 2023-24 but is now cooling due to high politics and the fading military Keynesianism boost. Sequential growth has bordered on a downturn in early 2025, though annual growth should remain above 1%. With softer growth and inflation easing from its near 10% peak, the CBR began rate cuts in June (from 21% to 20%) and we see the policy rate falling into 15-16% range by year end. A stronger rule has supported disinflation, but we now see it in overvalued territory, and expect renewed depreciation to emerge by the autumn. If the war continues beyond 2025, lower oil and slowing non-oil revenues would force more painful budget consolidation.EconomicsGrowth forecasts are significantly reduced (0.8% this year, 1.7% in 2026) due to domestic uncertainty and weak external demand. Tentative growth signals are encouraging for Q2, and the latest rate cut should help cement the cyclical recovery. We are yet to get clarity on any tariff deal with the US, but this is likely to prove disinflationary, which with the new aim to anchor inflation at 3% gives scope for another rate cut this year - likely September. We await September MPC, FATF Greylist removal in October, and improving terms of trade to keep confidence on the up. These would be necessary to partly counter the effects of lower prices on nominal GDP and fiscal revenue.Cash bonds: overweightGiven the ongoing outperformance, valuation vs externals as well as fundamentals looks less attractive. Nonetheless, we still expect the rally in local bonds to extend further into H2 on the back of ongoing gradual rate cuts, foreign inflows, stable FX, and well-anchored inflation. However, the game changer for South African fixed income is the change to the inflation target. This should lead to a more cautious SARB in the near-term but open the door for a lower neutral rate, consequently flattening the curve. The outlook for ultra remains challenging given ongoing unfavorable fiscal dynamics, however, the steepness of the 10Y-20Y curve is well reflecting the risks. We have lowered our year-end forecast for 10Y bonds to now 9.4% with room to rally further. Given the steepness of the curve, we recommend investors to move further out the curve and expect flat-flattening with most value in 2040.Long EURZARLocal rates: flatterChanges to the inflation target should not lead to a front-loaded aggressive easing cycle, given rising spot inflation in H2 and inflation expectations not yet anchored at 3%. We therefore expect a gradual further easing cycle but with a significantly lower neutral rate. This should lead to a bull-flattening of the curve. We recommend investors to stay in roll-rich 1y1y-5y5y IRS flatterers as our top trade.Top trade: 1y1y-5y5y IRS flattererFX: tactically bearishWe see scope for some weakness in the rand over the summer. The SARB's shift in tone on the inflation target may raise question marks about their reaction function, seasonality is weak over August and positioning is longLong EURZAR
Source:Deutsche Bank
Figure 8:CEEMEA Country views

CountryAsset classFundamentals/DriversTop TradesCEEMEA high-yielders (contd.)Economic activity grew by 1% QoQ in Q1 2025, after a strong end to the year in 2024; however, tightening financial conditions and a weaker external growth outlook are projected to restrain future expansion, with leading indicators for Q2 already signaling a deceleration in domestic demand, further compounded by persistent weakness in manufacturing activity. Concurrently, inflation continued its downward trend, supported by improved inflation expectations, limited exchange rate depreciation, and moderating wage pressures, bringing consumer price inflation to 35.0% in June 2025. Despite potential temporary interruptions from recent market volatility, we anticipate price pressures will ease in the coming months, with exchange rate stability and slowing domestic demand contributing to lower inflation. Although persistent services inflation remains a challenge, we forecast a 29.5% inflation by the end of 2025, primarily driven by a negative output gap, real appreciation in lira, and improved inflation expectations. In response to market volatility in March 2025 and sustained pressure on reserves, the CBT reversed its previous easing cycle hiking its key rate to 46%. We expect the CBT to continue its easing cycle in H2 after 300bps cut in July thanks to falling inflation, stabilization in financial markets and recovery in reserves. We forecast policy rate at 36.0% by year-end, alongside the active use of macroprudential policies to prevent premature easing of financial conditions during the easing cycle.TurkeyCash bonds: strong overweightTurkish bonds have recently outperformed but likely have more to go as we continue to see a number of supportive arguments. The impact of the VaR shock on domestic inflation was limited as we had expected and the latest inflation print is surprised to the downside confirming our constructive view. Additionally, FX reserve levels have started to recover and the situation looks much more stable again. Inflation is expected to further decline in H2 and most likely reach 29%-30%. After the CBT re-started its easing cycle with a 300bps rate cut in July, we expect further easing over the upcoming meetings with room for the key rate to reach 36%-likely offering support to bonds in the belly. Bond supply remains high, however, the Treasury will focus on other financial instruments over the summer. This should provide more room for ASW-spreads to tighten. We keep our strong overweight on local bonds and see most value in 5Y bonds. We justify this with high risk-neutral rates, wide ASW-spreads, gradually falling inflation, and ongoing rate cuts at each upcoming meeting. Positioning remains light and valuation not yet too expensive.FX: bullishHaving stayed on the sidelines over the first four months of this year, we turned bullish again in May. First, there are signs of stabilisation in CBT reserves after a significant drain after the volatility in March. Importantly, most of the drain stemmed from foreign outflows rather than onshore retail demand for dollars, which leaves positioning much cleaner. Second, the summer is supportive for Turkey's current account due to tourism revenues. Oil prices should prove another tailwind for an improvement in Turkey's current account. Third, carry is back at very attractive levels at just under 50% on a three month (annualised) basis. Diminishing pressure on the currency is illustrated by Turkey's cross currency basis which is normalising. Week in CEEMEA- What you need to know for the week ahead- Poland: discussing NBP, inflation and fiscal
Egypt (CBE): One Big Cut- Hungary: NBH maintained its hawkish stance in August- Kazakhstan: another hawkish hold from the NBK
\*\*\*Please see here for the original report, published on 29 August\*\*\*

At its August meeting this week, the CBE cut its rates by 200bps, in line with our out- of- consensus forecast (vs. market consensus: 1x150bps and 4x100bps). Consequently, the policy rate, overnight lending rate, and main operations rate were lowered to \(22\%\) , \(23\%\) , and \(22.50\%\) , respectively. As argued in our preview, the amalgam of domestic, regional, and global developments made this week's meeting an opportune time to opt for a sizable cut, including monthly deflation for two consecutive months, a supportive currency, and contained upside risks (e.g., potential capital outflows in response to geopolitical deterioration). All in all, we keep our view unchanged, expecting an overall rate cut of 725bps this year, with this week's rate leading to a cumulative rate cut of 525bps in 2025, leaving an additional 200bps for Q4. In this report, we highlight key elements from the press release and our monetary policy outlook.

First, the press release highlights the overall disinflationary trend, including the monthly deflation witnessed in both headline and core inflation over the past two months - suggesting an improvement in inflation expectations. We add that the latter was also helped by stability in currency, clearance of the import backlog (and the subsequent improvement in the supply chain), and the elimination of FX shortages. In addition, in line with our forecast (see our Inflation Monitor here), the CBE expects inflation to average \(14 - 15\%\) in 2025. We flag, however, that the pace of fiscal consolidation around the completion of the IMF's \(5^{\text{th}}\) review (likely in Q4) will be key in determining the magnitude of upside risks to this forecast. When it comes to growth, the CBE now forecasts stronger growth momentum for Q2 2025, of \(5.4\%\) , to be driven by the non- petroleum manufacturing and tourism sectors. Despite this continued recovery, estimated at \(- 4.5\%\) in FY24/25 (vs. \(2.4\%\) witnessed in FY23/24), the CBE expects demand- side inflationary pressures to remain contained in the short term, supported by the current monetary policy stance that is consistent with the expected disinflation path. Finally, the CBE argues that these favorable developments, including the improvement witnessed in underlying dynamics (see Figure 11) and supportive developments in the EGP, have created a conducive

environment for proceeding with its easing cycle. The CBE deems a 200bps cut appropriate for sustaining its disinflationary path, anchoring inflation expectations, and steering inflation toward its target of an average of \(7\%\) ( 2ppt) in Q4 2026 and \(5\%\) ( 2ppt) in Q4 2028.

Policy outlook: Overall, we maintain our outlook unchanged for 2025, expecting another 200bp rate cut in Q4, leading to a cumulative rate cut of 725bps in 2025. We highlight that Q4 easing will be conditional on the macroeconomic and geopolitical environment remaining favorable at both a domestic and global level. Here, it will be key to track the implication of a potential reimposition of UN sanctions on Iran for the region in the coming few weeks.

In addition, in terms of timing and distribution of the expected cuts, the latter are likely to be influenced by the completion date of the \(5^{\text{th}}\) IMF Review (likely in Q4), which tends to come with additional fiscal reforms (such as, another round of fuel hikes to reach cost recovery). Under these assumptions, where the authorities opt for some additional reforms earlier in Q4, we believe that November \(20^{\text{th}}\) and December \(25^{\text{th}}\) meetings will be more appropriate for remaining rate cuts. Until we gather more information about the direction of reforms and progress on the IMF Pending Review, we leave our pencilled in forecast unchanged (0bpXOctober, 100bpXNovember, 100bpXDecember).

To conclude, given a persistent level of uncertainty at the global level, including around the potential implication of US trade wars, progress on the divestment of SOEs and the completion of the country's pending IMF review will help in cementing Egypt's attractive position in Q4 (see figure Figure 12 and Figure 13) as well as (partially) offsetting forgone Suez Canal revenue.

The NBH left its policy rate unchanged at \(6.50\%\) at its meeting this week, in line with our and consensus expectations.

The NBH communication once again was broadly unchanged from last time. In the post- meeting press conference, governor Varga maintained the hawkish tone - noting fiscal risks and stressing that still high inflation expectations remain inconsistent with price stability. The NBH statement continued to stress the need for tight monetary policy conditions and a "careful and patient" approach, on the back of upside risks to inflation and increased global uncertainty. The statement also maintained the language on upside risks from still high inflation expectations and high corporate repricing (in items outside the scope of the government's measures) - though it did note declining wage growth and the dampening effect of the government's price measures on core inflation dynamics so far. The NBH also continued to see upside risks to household lending growth, mainly due to the government's recent loan programmes and subsidies. In fact, on fiscal developments, the press statement was slightly more hawkish than before, noting that the deficit- increasing effect of recent measures (though limited this year) may

be more significant next year. In the post- meeting press conference, governor Varga, however, noted that the NBH was not considering revising the fiscal forecasts for now, as the central bank believed in the government's commitment to the deficit target. Meanwhile, on global developments, the NBH sounded more optimistic on global growth given declining trade- related uncertainty following confirmation of the US- EU trade deal in particular, and noted the decline in energy prices as well as market repricing of the Fed rate path lower.

Monetary Policy Outlook. We believe the continued cautious approach of the central bank implies rate cuts before November this year look unlikely, especially with headline inflation (in annual terms) only likely to ease more meaningfully in Q4. That said, given a weak growth outlook, tight financial conditions and likely improvement in inflation expectations ahead, we continue to expect that room to ease policy rates does exist towards the end of the year. The government's price measures in food, non- food goods and various service sectors have kept a lid on inflationary pressures, and these have now been extended until end- November, in line with our expectations (we in fact expect them to be extended further until at least Q1 next year). Meanwhile, subdued imported inflation and cost dynamics, a declining trend in wage growth, easing labour market tightness (as measured by the job vacancy rate), along with more favourable commodity price dynamics and relative FX strength (despite some weakening recently), should also further support softer inflation ahead (towards c. \(3.5\%\) by year end).

Apart from favourable inflation dynamics in Q4, we believe external dynamics - relative HUF strength, and a likely September Fed rate cut (our US economists revised their Fed call post the Jackson Hole Symposium and now expect 2x25bps fed rate cuts this year in September and December) should also support rate easing from the NBH ahead. Therefore, we expect 50bps of rate easing this year, likely only starting in November, to take policy rate to \(6\%\) by end 2025. For next year, we believe the room for extensive easing has narrowed given an expected growth recovery in Hungary as well as broader Europe. We still see room for rate easing in early 2026, towards a terminal rate of \(5.50\%\) .
Kazakhstan: another hawkish hold from the NBK \*\*\*Please see here for the original report, published on 29 August\*\*\*

The NBK kept its key rate unchanged at \(16.5\%\) in line with our expectations and a slight majority of analysts in the BBG survey (3x unchanged, 2x50bps hike). After the NBK delivered a 125bps front- loaded hike in March, the MPC remained on hold in April, June, and July. However, with inflation accelerating, the real rates buffer the NBK built had started to decrease and we expected this decision to be a close call. This meeting was a forecast meeting and we had argued that no revision or only a small change to the inflation forecast could allow the NBK to remain on hold again. And indeed, the MPC only made a minor adjustment to the inflation forecast for this year bringing it to \(11\% - 12.5\%\) (slightly up from \(10.5\% - 12.5\%\) ).

The statement. As we expected, the MPC highlighted the flat annual headline inflation print in July, and noted that food inflation overtook service price inflation as the largest contributor to headline CPI after a slowdown in the latter. The monthly run- rate has also come down to \(+0.7\) pp but remains above the average for this time of the year (+0.4pp), while core and seasonally adjusted inflation also saw slightly softer prints. However, despite the slowdown, inflation remains elevated and inflationary pressures persist on the back of ongoing tariff reforms, fiscal stimulus, and stable consumer demand, supported, among other things, by high rates of
retail lending growth. Inflation expectations remain volatile and have deteriorated again most recently with household inflation expectations reaching \(14.2\%\) in July.

The MPC also remains focused on external drivers of inflation and, in particular, discussed rising global food prices as well as inflation in Russia still being elevated despite the recent disinflationary trend. In the NBK's assessment, external monetary conditions have slightly worsened since its May forecast round amidst slower easing expected from the Fed and the ECB striking a cautious tone amidst uncertainties associated with global trade conflicts.

Updated forecasts. In terms of its macro forecasts, revisions were small and contained to this year. As noted, the NBK revised up its inflation forecast for this year only slightly, and left the 2026 forecast \((9.5\% - 11.5\%)\) and the 2027 forecast \((5.5\% - 7.5\%)\) unchanged. GDP growth for this year was slightly increased as well to now \(5.5\% - 6.5\%\) (up from \(5\% - 6\%\) ) and left in place for 2026 \((4\% - 5\%)\) and 2027 \((3.5\% - 4.5\%)\) . The Brent forecast also reflected a slight improvement and was revised to 67.8 USD per barrel (up from 65) with the forecast for 2026 and 2027 remaining in place (60 across both years).

August inflation. After the annual run- rate consistently surprised to the upside of expectations throughout most of the year, the close to flat print in July was an early sign of inflationary pressures easing slightly. Food price inflation has picked up significantly over the last few months on the back of a weaker exchange rate, especially against the ruble, rising global prices and reports of some domestic price speculation. Ongoing utility tariff reforms continue to feed through into paid services inflation with the electricity tariff hike that came into effect in August likely exerting some near- term upward pressure. The disinflationary impact of the government halting further tariff hikes in Q4 will likely only become visible in the inflation run- rate towards the end of the year. For the upcoming August CPI print, we expect inflation to see further upside pressure and to reach \(12.1\%\) YoY.

Outlook. The NBK noted that the ongoing changes to minimum reserve requirements, including a further increase in September, should contribute to tighter monetary conditions and improve policy transmission. However, the NBK was also very explicit in signaling that, absent a significant slowdown in inflation, it would tighten monetary conditions at the next meetings. The MPC's key rate forecast will be available in the upcoming Monetary Policy Report (out on the \(3^{\text{rd}}\) of September) and could see an upward revision to the current baseline of the NBK staying on hold into year- end. The next two inflation prints (August & September) will be available ahead of the next meeting \((10^{\text{th}}\) October) and will likely prove decisive as to whether the NBK opts for a hike or not. The bar to a significant slowdown in inflation is, however, high given that August inflation will likely see upside pressure from electricity tariff hikes.

We expect the headline print to slow further in August to \(2.5\%\) YoY (prev. \(2.7\%\) ). A decline in the monthly run- rate (following the seasonally higher July number) should support the moderation. Food price inflation is likely to remain low - forward- looking indicators of food price inflation have softened recently, and the data for selected food item prices for August points to a \(- 0.9\%\) MoM decline. Fuel prices are also expected to add to disinflation with weekly pump price data so far pointing to a c.- 0.8% MoM decline in August. Low industrial producer price inflation also points to subdued inflation in durable goods like household items and vehicles for August. Meanwhile, we expect the services inflation run- rate to moderate slightly, as the seasonal effects of package holidays in July drop out - but
remain stickier, especially as imputed rental costs remain elevated.

remain stickier, especially as imputed rental costs remain elevated.Inflation Outlook: We expect inflation to moderate marginally for the rest of the year in the Czech Republic. We have revised the inflation forecasts path higher for the rest of the year on the back of more resilient domestic demand than earlier expected, a decline in trade uncertainty, and stickiness in services inflation. However, we believe that weak imported inflation, subdued industrial producer prices, and ongoing CZK strength are likely to lead to inflationary pressures remaining contained. Meanwhile, favourable commodity price dynamics along with a weaker dollar should lead to lower fuel prices in the Czech Republic. A further electricity and gas price decline is also planned for September (by E.ON), which adds to downside pressures. Volatile food price inflation is a risk to our forecasts - but forward- looking indicators point to softening pressures ahead. Upside pressures stem from accelerating house price inflation feeding through to CPI via both market rentals and imputed rentals costs. However, there are now signs that services inflation, excluding rentals, is beginning to ease from stickier levels. Overall, we believe that headline inflation should moderate to close to the CNB's 2% target in the second half of this year (DBE: +2.2% at end- 2025) (despite upside pressures stemming from house price inflation, still- elevated inflation expectations and stickier services pricing) - before positive growth spillovers from German fiscal spending take effect in 2026.

In Q1 2025, GDP grew by \(1.0\%\) QoQ, following a strong \(1.7\%\) QoQ in Q4 2024. Net exports were the primary growth driver, rebounding from the previous quarter's drag as export growth outpaced imports, likely due to pre- trade war stockpiling. Fiscal expansion also contributed, with government expenditures up \(2.1\%\) QoQ. While consumption saw a mild contraction, it showed no signs of significant slowdown, supported by loan growth, year- start wage hikes, and the CBT's initial easing cycle.

The monetary tightening after March's market turbulence is expected to weigh on Q2 domestic demand, leading to a mild slowdown rather than a sharp contraction. Several indicators confirm this deceleration: the services production index remained stable in Q2 (vs \(3.1\%\) in Q1), retail sales grew \(3.9\%\) (vs \(3.1\%\) in Q1), and

industrial production grew \(0.7\%\) (vs \(1.7\%\) in Q1). Construction slowed significantly to \(0.8\%\) QoQ in Q2 (vs \(11.2\%\) in Q1). Labor market indicators also suggest softening, with elevated labor underutilization. Net exports should remain restrictive in Q2 due to strong import growth post- March volatility and mounting trade uncertainty. Overall, we expect Q2 growth momentum to decelerate to \(0.6\%\) QoQ while we see YoY growth accelerating to \(3.6\%\) (vs \(2.0\%\) YoY) thanks to base effects.

Leading indicators signal challenging conditions for Q3 2025 activity on the back of sluggish domestic and external demand conditions, though we do not see a sharp contraction. Consumption goods imports keep its strength, and labor market indicators showed mild improvement in July. On the other hand, Manufacturing PMI continued to deteriorate to 45.9 in July (vs 47.1 in Q2). We expect below- potential economic activity to persist amidst a tight policy stance and muted loan growth. However, a restart of the easing cycle, credit packages, policymakers' gradual approach to disinflation, and an expected recovery in major trading partners (especially Europe) suggest the soft- landing scenario will persist in H2 2025. We maintain our \(3.0\%\) growth forecast for FY 2025, aligning with our gradual disinflation expectation.

Source : Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank
Figure 23: We expect economic activity to remain contained in 2025.
Source : Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank

Consumer prices in July rose by \(2.1\%\) MoM, an acceleration from June's \(1.4\%\) driven predominantly by administered price and tax hikes, including a 0.9ppts contribution from mid- year tax and natural gas price increases. Despite this monthly uptick, the July inflation figure fell below expectations for the third straight month. We anticipate that the temporary inflationary factors seen in July will subside in August, leading to a slowdown in monthly inflation after July's temporary rise. Specifically, the effect of the natural gas price increase, which was reflected in the July data, will reverse in August. Coupled with favorable international oil prices and the July impact of SCT adjustments, energy inflation is projected to be noticeably lower. While food inflation is expected to be less favorable this month due to accelerating fresh fruit and vegetable prices and a \(20\%\) nationwide bread price hike impacting processed food, core goods inflation should soften. This softening is driven by a slower pace of depreciation and weakening demand affecting FX and demand- sensitive goods. However, services inflation, particularly from education and rent, will likely temper any significant fall in overall
core inflation. Our overall projection for monthly inflation is \(1.8\%\) . If realized, this would bring the annual inflation rate to \(32.6\%\) .

We expect inflation will continue its declining path for the remainder of the year as FX- driven cost pressures are expected to remain under control due to orderly depreciation, coupled with a rising contribution from weakening demand conditions and easing wage pressures, all of which should help further reduce inflationary pressures. We forecast inflation to decrease to \(29.5\%\) by the end of 2025. Volatility in energy prices stemming from geopolitical risks, concerns regarding food inflation due to seasonal shocks such as frost experienced in spring and drought in summer months, and higher- than- expected stickiness in services inflation pose upside risks to our forecasts.

Back in July, headline CPI marginally picked up again and reached \(8.9\%\) YoY. Two months earlier in May, strong base effects from last year's energy tariff hikes for households outweighed the upward push from this year's more modest tariff adjustment. Headline inflation saw a sharp decrease from earlier \(10.1\%\) and has since proved sticky at current levels.

Looking ahead to the August CPI print, we expect inflation to further stabilise. Service price inflation is likely to remain sticky as the latest energy tariff hike is feeding through. Additionally, food prices are likely to see further upside as base effects continue to fade. However, non- food inflation is likely to remain comparatively moderate as sound strength against the dollar has continued and the sound even strengthened slightly against the ruble. Against this backdrop, we expect inflation to soften slightly and return to \(8.7\%\) YoY in August.

Outlook. More favourable base effects following last year's energy tariff liberalisation are likely to be initially offset by the second phase of energy tariff hikes that went ahead in May. However, eventually we expect the annual run rate to return to a slow disinflationary path. Demand- driven inflation is likely to stay elevated amid fiscal spending, in connection with the reform agenda, rising real wages, and continued high retail credit growth rates. However, inflation expectations have continued to improve. The CBU has pushed its year- end forecast slightly higher and expects the annual inflation run- rate to reach the upper bound of the 7- 8% forecast range by the end of 2025. The CBU only expects the 5% inflation target to come into view in H2- 26.

Source : Deutsche Bank, Haver Analytics

Inflation surprised sharply to the downside again in July, falling below our and consensus forecasts. At \(12.1\%\) YoY, inflation pressures are the lowest since September 2021 and close to the BoG's inflation target range.

We see a moderate rise in inflation in August to \(13\%\) YoY, though acknowledge risks are to the downside. We expect hardly any inflation on the month, however, in August last year, prices dropped by \(2.2\%\) MoM. While we could see another seasonal repeat of lower prices, the stronger exchange rate has already led to larger reductions in many items such as furnishings, transport, recreation and education.

The cedi also weakened by nearly \(8\%\) since June, which could lead to some retailers rebuilding buffers. Still, we penciled in a \(0.2\%\) MoM decline in food prices following a \(0.6\%\) MoM increase in July, while transport prices could be skewed higher following the implementation of the energy levy hike in July. Transport operators report resulted in a higher fuel price of GHS1/l. This along with high maintenance costs and poor road infrastructure may lead their transport fares up by \(20\%\) this month, following earlier declines this year. However, these adjustments are unlikely to have a material impact on retail inflation, thanks to the sharp moderation in industrial PPI to \(3.8\%\) YoY in July (from \(5.8\%\) ), showing across the board easing in inflation pressure, including construction and services.

Ghana's inflation outlook remains positive thanks to a stronger cedi, lower oil prices and better anchored inflation expectations. Indications that VAT could be reduced by \(1\%\) - p net year should further cement a lower inflation profile which we now see settling at \(15.1\%\) this year (previously \(16.3\%\) ) and \(5.3\%\) next year (was \(6.4\%\) ). Year- end inflation is likely to fall to \(6\%\) - the lower limit of the \(6 - 10\%\) target range, and well below the BoG's prediction of \(10\%\) . High base effects could mean that inflation undershoot the lower limit of the target, but we see inflation re- entering the target band in 2H26 as gradual cedi weakness emerges from here. More favorable global cereal crop conditions would further assist the outlook, however the emergence of black pod disease in some local areas need close monitoring as this could negatively affect cocoa crops. Transport prices are currently seen in deflation for the next several months thanks to high base effects. As such, there may be more upside risks to our forecast especially if cedi weakness surprise to the upside and oil prices drift higher. Following the 300bps cut in rates in July, we expect the BoG to cut rates by \(2.5\%\) in September and November, which should take the MPR to \(20\%\) by year- end.
Figure 30: Steep inflation descent underway
Source:Haver Analytics,Deutsche Bank
Figure 31: With 500bps of cuts still on the table, real rates remain at historical highs
Source:Haver Analytics,Deutsche Bank

The NBP is due to meet for its September MPC meeting next week, and in our baseline scenario we expect the MPC to deliver a 25bps rate cut to take the policy rate to \(4.75\%\) . Recent NBP communication, and inflation dynamics data support our view. However, the increase in fiscal risks (as reiterated by the 2026 draft budget confirmed this week) and the ongoing uncertainty on the future of electricity prices, a pause in easing should not be completely ruled out for next week in our view.
In this report, we review this week's August flash CPI release, discuss the draft budget, and preview the MPC meeting next week.

According to the flash print of August CPI, headline inflation slowed further to \(2.8\%\) YoY in Poland (prev. \(3.1\%\) ). The print was not only softer than last month, but also slightly softer than both our and consensus expectations of \(2.9\%\) . In monthly terms, prices declined \(- 0.1\%\) MoM - this was in line with our estimates. According to the limited details released so far, the monthly decline was led by a decline in fuel prices \((- 1.9\%\) MoM), and continued disinflation in food prices \((- 0.1\%\) MoM) - both broadly in line with our expectations. Based on these details, core inflation in annual terms should also decline further in August, likely to c. \(3.1\%\) YoY (prev. \(3.3\%\) ) according to our estimates - this, if realized would be the lowest core inflation print since the pandemic. As we had highlighted in our preview, weak cost pressures, relative FX strength, and reversal of seasonal effects in recreation & culture services prices is likely to have supported a softer core inflation print in August.
Figure 32: Overall prices declined slightly in August, softer than historical trends
Source: Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank Research
Figure 33: Our estimates suggest a further slowdown in core inflation likely
Source: Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank Research

Looking ahead, we expect headline inflation to remain slightly below \(3\%\) for the rest of the year. Subdued PPI, moderating trend of wage growth, and slow underlying demand- pull pressures continue to limit underlying inflationary pressures. Easing house price inflation should also positively impact rental dynamics ahead. Electricity price dynamics for Q4 have become more uncertain after the President's decision to veto legislation on extending the price caps beyond September. However, in our baseline scenario, we do not expect material upside from electricity prices in Q4 - due to a combination of some further legislative measures (with government now expected to submit its proposals to parliament in early September), as well as decline in regulated prices (to be set by mid- September),

though undoubtedly there is now more uncertainty. Inflation should further decline towards \(2.5\%\) in early 2026, provided the President blocks the larger excise duty hikes proposed by the government for January 2026 (which he has indicated his intention to do).

In the draft 2026 budget finalised by the government this week, general government deficit has been pencilled in at \(- 6.5\%\) of GDP, marking only a limited consolidation from the revised \(- 6.9\%\) deficit target for this year. For this year, we had maintained that the government's earlier deficit target was too optimistic, but the revised \(6.9\%\) is worse than our own forecasts, and makes for a weaker starting point for next year.

In terms of the breakdown, projected revenues for 2026 are expected to improve from this year's levels - mainly due to the proposed increase in taxes on banks, proposed larger excise duty hikes on alcohol and tobacco products, improved growth outlook, and changes to VAT regime (increase in the exemption limit from PLN 200K to PLN 240K and implementation of e- invoicing). Improvements in revenue is likely to be partially dampened by the continued impact of changes to local government financing implemented this year, i.e. higher transfers of PIT revenues from central budget to local administrations. Meanwhile, expenditures are likely to remain broadly unchanged - with continued significant social sector spending ("Active Parent" programme, Family \(800+\) programme, pensions bonuses, etc.), and high defence spending (c. \(4.8\%\) of GDP in 2026). The budget also pencils in higher healthcare spending, and continued focus on infrastructure development (to be financed out of the budget, BGK, as well as European funds), and investments related to nuclear energy and AI development.

Overall, the revisions to 2025 budget were larger than expected, and the lack of more substantial consolidation in 2026 remains concerning. Moreover, implementation risks to the 2026 budget remains high, as uncertainty regarding the President's support for consolidation measures further complicates things. The government has submitted bills in parliament to implement the increased tax on banks, and the larger excise duty increases - but the President has expressed his intention to veto further tax increases, which increases risks to budget implementation.
Figure 34: 2025 budget outturns running well-below last year's levels
Source: Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank Research
Figure 35: The government now projects a wider deficit this year, and limited consolidation in 2026
Source: Haver Analytics, Deutsche Bank Research

In our baseline scenario we expect the MPC to deliver a 25bps rate cut next week to take the policy rate to \(4.75\%\) . Next week's meeting is the first MPC meeting after the summer break in August and therefore the first since the surprise move in July. Since the July meeting, inflation has continued to moderate - the July print (though surprising slightly to the upside) saw a sharp deceleration to within the NBP's target band, due to energy price- related base effects. August inflation has declined further, in fact surprising slightly to the downside of consensus expectations and is now below \(3\%\) . Accompanied by a likely further slowdown in core inflation - the data would justify another 25bps rate cut from the central bank next week, especially given that real policy rates are in fact now higher than they were at the time of the July meeting.

Recent MPC communication has remained open to a September rate cut. MPC member Wnorowski noted this week that a rate cut next week was likely, and Duda also did not rule it out completely (though indicating her preference to be more cautious). At his last press conference in July, governor Glapinski had also noted that a rate cut in September remained possible, if inflation data remained supportive. Along with the softer- than- expected wage data recently limiting upside risks to inflation, as well as the inflation data, we think that the comments indicate that the NBP is more likely to continue easing next week. That said, given increasing fiscal risks, and ongoing uncertainty on the future of electricity prices beyond September, it is possible the NBP remain more cautious at next week's meeting - and therefore a pause cannot be fully ruled out in our view.

In fact, in light of increasing uncertainty, we believe the central bank will be more cautious ahead. A number of factors are pointing to hawkish risks ahead - limited fiscal consolidation, inability of the President and government to come to an agreement on electricity price caps, potentially large excise duty hikes in early January which could be short- term inflationary, and recent (slightly) better- than- expected July activity data. We, therefore, expect the MPC to pause in October to reevaluate, and resuming easing in November when the updated projections are available.

Overall, we expect another 75bps of rate easing in total this year remains possible. This is on the higher end of estimates suggested by most MPC communication so far (including Wnorowski this week who indicated a pause post September), but if PLN remains relatively stable and inflation remains close to \(3\%\) in the second half of the year (as in our baseline, assuming limited upside pressure from electricity prices in Q4), we do think it is possible that the NBP can take policy rate to \(4.25\%\) by year end. Our US economists' recently revised Fed call, which now sees 2x25bps rate cuts this year in September and December, should also support our view.

Further easing to \(3.75\%\) in Q1- 26 does remain possible. That said, we see only a limited window for potential rate cuts next year - resilience of the overall domestic economy, stronger German growth next year, and ongoing domestic fiscal spending and looser financing conditions, make it more unlikely to see cuts beyond Q1 in our view, especially in an environment of elevated fiscal risks. Inflation, particularly core, is unlikely to therefore stay at \(2.5\%\) through 2026 - which is the key criteria for the governor to be able to see policy rates at \(3\%\) . We, therefore, believe that with inflation likely structurally higher, the NBP's terminal rate will be closer to \(3.75\%\) .
EM FX: Crowning glory
\*\*\*Please see here for the original report, published on 28 August\*\*\*

The Czech crown has been one of our highest bullish conviction views this year. Having performed well against both the euro and PLN, which has been has been our preferred expression since the May Blueprint, we remain structurally bullish. Indeed, we see the Czech exchange rate as one of the best expressions of the regime shift in German fiscal and defence policy.

1. Czechia's growth is highly correlated to Germany. Some simple regressions suggest the long run historical beta of Czech GDP to German GDP is 0.9, a number which doesn't diminish if taking a more recent sample period (Figure 36). This should not be a surprise given the economy's extremely tight supply chain and cross border linkages. The material upward revisions to German GDP growth engendered by the fiscal package earlier this year (our economist forecasts growth of 2% in 2026, a full percentage point above consensus) should therefore be reflected in Czechia's growth outlook.

2. The economy already enjoys a strong comparative advantage in defence. The Czech Republic has been a major arms producer for well over one hundred years. The tilt of European industrial policy with plans to spend EUR 800bn on defence over the next five years especially benefits the Czech export industry which has already seen a sharp rise in defence exports since the start of the Ukraine war (Figure 37), as we noted a couple of months back. Capacity in Czechia's extensive auto sector can also be utilised in the pivot towards defence. Finally, Czechia should be positively exposed to a Russia/Ukraine resolution due to its strong political linkages with Ukraine which could facilitate involvement in reconstruction efforts.

3. The labour market is close to full employment. Sizeable German fiscal spillovers coupled with the prospect of an easing of the domestic fiscal stance could dovetail with a labour market already close to full employment. The breakdown in the Czech Phillips curve since the pandemic appears to be correcting itself over the last year (figure 3) and we have previously noted the relatively unstocky nature of Czech wages in response to demand shocks. Given large labour capacity constraints in Germany, it would not be surprising to see material spillovers into wage growth in the Czech Republic and hence inflation.

4. Low realised vol offers a great investment opportunity. Because EUR/CZK has historically realised at low levels of volatility, positioning for a regime break is cheap via options. One pushback is the central bank may not want excessively large appreciation in the exchange rate. But Governor Michl has in recent years embraced a 'strong crown policy' and exchange rate appreciation may be a helpful dampener to inflation arising from the supply constraints highlighted above.

CEEMEA Inflation Monitor: Old friends, new fight
\*\*\*Please see here for the original report, published on 28 August\*\*\*

We present our August CEEMEA inflation monitor report. In this monthly report, we provide a comprehensive overview of country- level inflation developments, including their key drivers. We also provide our take on the near- and medium- term inflation outlooks and distinguish between common global and idiosyncratic drivers, including a sensitivity analysis based on our FX and oil price pass- through estimations. Owing to less frequent coverage, we have excluded Russia from this report. Thirteen countries are included in our report: Czech Republic, Egypt, Ghana, Hungary, Israel, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Poland, Romania, South Africa, Turkiye, Ukraine and Uzbekistan.

The July inflation landscape across CEEMEA continued with strong disinflation in most regions (Figure 41) coupled with downside surprises (Figure 42). Inflation eased further to \(10.8\%\) YoY on aggregate, down from \(11.1\%\) in June. Favourable base effects, stronger exchange rates and their impact on import prices as well as seasonal improvements in food prices encapsulate July's inflation narrative. However, inflation rose in South Africa, Romania, and Uzbekistan, but surprised to the upside in the latter two. In turn, inflation dropped by less than we had forecast in Poland. The impact of administered price adjustments and energy costs emerged as a significant upside driver (see Figure 43) and risk, notably in Romania, South Africa, and Turkiye. Romania saw a sharp acceleration due to the expiry of electricity price protections, leading to a substantial increase in household energy prices. South Africa's inflation was predominantly driven by electricity and higher than expected water tariff escalations, while Poland, despite more favourable base effects, saw a larger- than- expected increase in fuel prices as well as increase in household energy prices due to the reintroduction of a capacity fee. In turn, favourable base effects continued driving down inflation in Egypt, Turkiye, and Ghana (Figure 44). Despite the generally positive narrative, new and/or persistent inflation pressures are starting to become more challenging factors preventing further easing in some markets.

Our agri- commodity food leading indicator has signaled for some time that prices are likely to regain momentum into mid- year. Indeed, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, South Africa, and Hungary experienced persistent or rising food price pressures, stemming from factors like weak currency, specific supply shocks (meat in South Africa), or elevated producer prices. From here onwards, it seems that annual food inflation could start abating (Figure 45), especially as grains prices continue to ease amid an abundant supply outlook. Regional supply issues may also prove temporary (e.g. South Africa meat, Kazakhstan imports) or weak FX continue to pose challenges

Progress on disinflation remains encouraging, and cyclical inflation trends have responded to tight financial conditions in key markets in CEEMEA. Core inflation has largely tracked lower even during what has been a volatile and eventful year. While positive fx trends have been helpful, these are far from favourable in all markets (e.g Kazakhstan, Ukraine and Romania). Meanwhile, services inflation, which bears resemblance to our non- cyclical inflation gauge (i.e., inflation persistence) is showing signs of persistence or acceleration in several economies (Figure 46). While seasonality explain some of these increases (e.g. tourism related adjustments in Czech Republic) underlying demand, wage trends and or general service delivery issues remain notable problems for some markets. We will continue to monitor inflation expectations for signs of potential decoupling between goods and and some services inflation categories (e.g. health, and recreation and culture).

This somewhat cautious tone is also mirrored in the broader EM universe judging by slightly less positive inflation surprises (Figure 7) in July. Based on our analysis of inflation drivers (Figure 48), the CEEMEA inflation trend is now firmly being driven by disinflation in global factors (e.g. oil, food prices, the dollar) and countries that were lagging earlier disinflation cycles in the region, such as Nigeria, Ghana and Turkiye, are finally seeing idiosyncratic issues give way to disinflation. However, we still note the presence of sticky/rising domestic factors behind inflation outcomes in Ukraine and Kazakhstan, and more recently in Romania.

Figure 50: Inflation dynamics & CPI components

Despite the overarching disinflationary narrative, significant regional contrasts and idiosyncratic factors will drive diverse outcomes. Some economies, like the Czech Republic and Ghana, are expected to see continued moderation, supported by weak import inflation, favorable commodity prices, and stronger currencies. Conversely, others, such as Romania and Kazakhstan, face persistent upside risks from planned tax increases, ongoing utility tariff reforms, and loose fiscal stances. Services inflation remains a sticky component across many countries, influenced by resilient domestic demand, wage growth, and structural rigidities. Geopolitical factors, particularly in Ukraine and Israel, continue to introduce uncertainty and volatility.

Central and Eastern Europe (CEE): We have now revised our inflation forecast path higher for the rest of the year. In the Czech Republic, this is mainly a consequence of more resilient domestic demand than earlier expected, decline in trade uncertainty, and stickiness in services inflation. That said, we continue to expect the headline to moderate slightly over the coming months - due to weak import inflation, subdued PPI, stronger CZK and favourable commodity price dynamics. In Romania, the large upside surprise in July inflation, mainly due to the larger than expected impact of the electricity price removal has led to a further upward revision to the inflation path. Taking into account the tax increases as of August, headline inflation is now likely to reach \(c.10\%\) . We have also revised our forecasts slightly higher in Poland - following the upside surprise in July, but continue to expect the headline to remain close to \(3\%\) for the rest of the year (though Q4 household electricity prices remain a key source of uncertainty). In Hungary, we continue to expect headline inflation to moderate, especially in Q4, supported by likely continuation of government's price protections, weak domestic demand, and favourable imports costs.

Israel & Trkiye: Disinflation is expected to continue, aided by favorable base effects and tighter policies. However, the outlook is clouded by geopolitical risks, potential supply chain bottlenecks, and aggressive government spending in Israel. In Trkiye, disinflation is projected to be more gradual due to strong backward indexation in services inflation, despite controlled FX depreciation and weakening demand. FX stability and real appreciation remain crucial for sustained disinflation in both countries.

South Africa & Sub-Saharan Africa: The outlook is balanced, with South Africa's inflation close to bottoming out, Nigeria's remaining stickier, and Ghana's improving significantly. In South Africa, less fuel disinflation and rising services are expected to drive near- term trends. Nigeria's inflation should be supported by FX stability and subdued commodity prices, but high import reliance and infrastructure challenges pose key perils. Ghana's favorable outlook is primarily due to a much stronger cedi, though food and energy price risks remain.

Rest of Frontier Markets: Inflation dynamics are diverse. Egypt shows potential for significant easing, contingent on sustained currency stability and supply chain improvements, but faces upside risks from fiscal consolidation and food price shocks. Ukraine's inflation outlook remains highly uncertain due to the military situation, though improving food prices and international aid are expected to drive disinflation from a peak. Kazakhstan is projected to see continued upward pressure from tariff hikes and fiscal policies. Uzbekistan's inflation is likely to remain sticky due to energy tariff hikes, but is expected to return to a slow disinflationary path.

Sensitivity to oil & FX dynamics.We update our sensitivity analysis to commodity and FX movements. We include eight countries in our analysis. Assuming international Brent crude oil forecasts decline to USD 50/bl by year end, with \(10\%\) stronger FX (relative to our base- case scenario), our analysis implies an average decrease in headline inflation of 0.6pp by year end (from \(8.5\%\) to \(7.9\%\) ). The decline is most substantial in Turkiye (- 1.8pp), Israel (- 0.9pp) and Egypt(- 0.8pp), but also quite meaningful in South Africa and Romania.

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.
